Kematian Pegiat Lingkungan Golfrid Siregar 'Janggal', Internasional Minta Indonesia Usut Tuntas
01 Nov 2019, 05:40 by ABC
Kelompok aktivis lingkungan 'Friends of the Earth' telah mendatangi kantor Konsulat Jenderal RI di Melbourne, Australia, Kamis siang (31/10/2019) untuk menyampaikan surat tekait meninggalnya Golfrid Siregar.
KP FOE Unjuk Rasa

240 organisasi dunia meminta Indonesia terbuka dalam mengusut kematian Golfrid Siregar
Kasus terakhir yang diperjuangkan Golfrid adalah pembangunan PLTA Batang Toru
KJRI Melbourne telah menerima surat yang akan diteruskan ke KBRI Canberra

Kepada ABC Indonesia, Sam Cossar mengatakan mereka menyampaikan kecurigaan kematian Golfrid Siregar memiliki kaitan dengan profesinya sebagai pengacara lingkungan bersama WALHI di Sumatera Utara.
"Kami meminta agar pemerintah Indonesia membuka penyelidikan yang transparan atas meninggalnya Golfrid," kata Sam dari 'Friends of the Earth'.
Mereka juga mengatakan penyelidikan tidak hanya harus dilakukan secara independen, tapi juga lewat tim khusus yang dibuat langsung oleh Komnas HAM.
Ada pula tuntutan agar Presiden Joko Widodo membuat peraturan yang menjamin dan melindungi hak-hak aktivis lingkungan dan HAM, agar mencegah "kriminalisasi" bagi mereka yang mencoba membongkar ketidakadilan.


Golfrid Siregar (kiri) dikenal sebagai aktivis dan pengacara lingkungan dan membongkar kasus yang melibatkan banyak perusahaan di Sumatera Utara. Foto: WALHI Sumatera Utara

Golfrid Siregar ditemukan tak sadarkan diri dengan tubuh terlentang dan sebuah motor di sebuah jalanan di kota Medan (Sumatera Utara) 3 Oktober 2019 , dini hari.
Pria berusia 34 tahun tersebut meninggal tiga hari setelah mendapat perawatan di rumah sakit karena luka di bagian kepala.
"Yang bersangkutan meninggal karena kecelakaan tunggal," ujar Kapolda Sumatera Utara, Irjen Pol Andriyanto dalam sebuah konferensi pers pertengahan Oktober lalu.
Polisi juga mengaku telah adanya bukti jika Golfrid mengkonsumsi alkohol sebelum mengendarai motor.
Pernah melapor adanya dugaan korupsi


Jenazah Golfrid dibawa ke RS Bhayangkara Medan untuk dilakukan autopsi dua hari setelah dinyatakan meninggal dunia. Foto: Antara, Nur Aprilliana Br. Sitorus

Namun WALHI mengatakan ada "kejanggalan" dari kematian Golfrid, seperti ditemukannya keretakan pada kepala, luka memar di mata kanan, pakaian yang banyak lumpur.
Golfrid juga sempat dilaporkan hilang dan mendapat ancaman sebelumnya.
Dalam sebuah konferensi pers yang digelar di Jakarta, 10 Oktober lalu, WALHI mengatakan ada indikasi Golfrid telah mendapat penganiyaaan.
"Alhmarhum Golfrid ini salah satu aktivis, kuasa hukum dan kunci dari kasus yang ditangani WALHI, salah satunya adalah PLTA Batang Toru," ujar Zenzi Suhadi, Kepala Departemen Advokasi Eksekutif Nasional WALHI saat itu.
Baru setelah WALHI memberikan pernyataan soal kecurigaan atas kematian Golfrid, Polda Sumut mengajak WALHI Sumatera Utara untuk melakukan otopsi dan reka ulang kejadian.
Dari catatan 'Friends of the Earth' pembangunan PLTA Batang Toru adalah proyek kontroversial yang memberikan dampak pada lingkungan, sosial, keanekaragaman hayati dengan sejumlah "aktivitas yang mencurigakan yang dilakukan PT North Sumatera Hydro Energy sebagai pengembang proyek".
Sebagai perwakilan WALHI, ia mengugat perusahaan tersebut karena dianggap telah menyalahi sejumlah peraturan, termasuk melapor ke KPK dengan dugaan adanya potensi korupsi antara PT NSHE dan pemerintah setempat.
Golfrid juga sebelumnya aktif menyediakan layanan advokasi bagi warga yang pernah mengalami kerugian atau menyuarakan masalah penebangan pohon ilegal, pertambangan, atau perusakkan hutan.
Surat permintaan dari 240 organisasi

External Link: 
Twitter FOE Golfrid Siregar

Sam Cossar dari Friends of the Earth kepada Erwin Renaldi dari ABC Indonesia mengatakan surat yang ditujukan kepada pemerintah Indonesia telah ditandatangani oleh 240 organisasi pemerhati dan pembela lingkungan di lebih 70 negara.
Mereka pun telah mengirimkan surat kepada kantor-kantor Kedutaan Besar RI atau perwakilannya di kota-kota besar sejumlah negara, termasuk di Filipina, Jepang, Amerika Serikat, dan Eropa.
"Di Melbourne kami telah diterima oleh perwakilan ke KJRI dan melakukan juga dialog dengan baik-baik," kata Sam.
KJRI Melbourne telah mengkonfirmasi kehadiran lima orang dari 'Friends of the Earth' Australia dan menyerahkan langsung suratnya.
"Surat ditujukan kepada Kedutaan Indonesia di Canberra, sehingga kami akan meneruskannya," ujar Spica Alphanya Tutuhatunewa, Konjen RI di Melbourne kepada ABC Indonesia.
Baca berita lainnya dari Australia hanya di ABC Indonesia.

Death of Environmental Activist Golfrid Siregar 'Strange', International Asks Indonesia to Investigate Completely
Nov 1 2019, 05:40 by ABC
Environmental activist group 'Friends of the Earth' visited the Indonesian Consulate General's office in Melbourne, Australia, Thursday afternoon (10/31/2019) to deliver a letter regarding the death of Golfrid Siregar.
KP FOE Rallies

240 world organizations are asking Indonesia to be open in investigating the death of Golfrid Siregar
The last case that Golfrid is fighting for is the construction of the Batang Toru hydropower plant
The Indonesian Consulate General in Melbourne has received a letter which will be forwarded to the Indonesian Embassy in Canberra

To ABC Indonesia, Sam Cossar said they expressed suspicion that the death of Golfrid Siregar had something to do with his profession as an environmental lawyer with WALHI in North Sumatra.
"We request that the Indonesian government open a transparent investigation into the death of Golfrid," said Sam of 'Friends of the Earth'.
They also said the investigation must not only be carried out independently, but also through a special team made directly by Komnas HAM.
There are also demands that President Joko Widodo make regulations that guarantee and protect the rights of environmental and human rights activists, so as to prevent "criminalization" for those who try to expose injustice.


Golfrid Siregar (left) is known as an activist and environmental lawyer and is uncovering cases involving many companies in North Sumatra. Photo: WALHI North Sumatra

Golfrid Siregar was found unconscious with a supine body and a motorbike on a road in the city of Medan (North Sumatra) 3 October 2019, early morning.
The 34-year-old man died three days after receiving treatment at the hospital due to head injuries.
"He died due to a single accident," said North Sumatra Police Chief Inspector General Andriyanto at a press conference in mid-October.
The police also claimed there was evidence that Golfrid consumed alcohol before riding a motorcycle.
Have reported corruption allegations


Golfrid's body was taken to the Bhayangkara Hospital in Medan for an autopsy two days after he was declared dead. Photo: Antara, Nur Aprilliana Br. Sitorus

But WALHI said there were "irregularities" from Golfrid's death, such as the discovery of a crack in the head, bruises on the right eye, clothes that were muddy.
Golfrid was also reported to have disappeared and received threats before.
In a press conference held in Jakarta on October 10, WALHI said there were indications that Golfrid had been tortured.
"The late Golfrid is one of the activists, legal counsel and key of the case handled by WALHI, one of which is the Batang Toru Hydroelectric Power Plant," said Zenzi Suhadi, Head of WALHI's National Executive Advocacy Department at that time.
Only after WALHI gave a statement about suspicion of the death of Golfrid, the North Sumatra Regional Police invited WALHI North Sumatra to conduct an autopsy and reproduce the incident.
From the 'Friends of the Earth' note the construction of the Batang Toru Hydroelectric Power Plant is a controversial project that has an impact on the environment, social, biodiversity with a number of "suspicious activities carried out by PT North Sumatra Hydro Energy as the project developer".
As WALHI's representative, he sued the company for allegedly violating a number of regulations, including reporting to the KPK on suspicion of potential corruption between PT NSHE and the local government.
Golfrid has also been previously active in providing advocacy services for residents who have experienced losses or raised concerns about illegal logging, mining, or forest destruction.
Request letters from 240 organizations

External Link:
Twitter FOE Golfrid Siregar

Sam Cossar from Friends of the Earth to Erwin Renaldi from ABC Indonesia said the letter addressed to the Indonesian government had been signed by 240 organizations of environmentalists and advocates in more than 70 countries.
They have also sent letters to the offices of the Indonesian Embassy or their representatives in major cities in a number of countries, including in the Philippines, Japan, the United States, and Europe.
"In Melbourne we have been received by representatives to the Consulate General and have a good dialogue," Sam said.
The Indonesian Consulate General in Melbourne has confirmed the presence of five people from Australia's 'Friends of the Earth' and submitted the letter in person.
"The letter is addressed to the Indonesian Embassy in Canberra, so we will continue it," Spica Alphanya Tutuhatunewa, Indonesian Consul General in Melbourne, told ABC Indonesia.
